title: In a Chapter 7 Bankruptcy, where can I find out what expenses are allowed?
question: I have a Sep-Ira that I contribute to when I can. Can that be listed as an average expense on the Schedule J. I meet the Means Test for Income, but my disposable income is $500 and if I deduct the Sep-IRA of $150-200 it would lower the net disposable income.
answers:
In Riverside they are allowing the deduction for the IRA as long as you can show that you have been making the same amount of contributions to the IRA in the past. What they do not allow is for you to suddenly start making a contribution that you have no prior history making.

There are lists of forgotten expenses, daily, misc type expenses that eat your pocketbook.

If you are putting $500 a month in savings then you have listed all your expenses....but if you are unable to pay the minimum on your card and keep your installment payments current then you have probably overlook a few occasional and recurring essential or ordinary and reasonable living expenses...

http://www.justice.gov/ust/eo/bapcpa/20091101/meanstesting.htm
(This may give you an idea or two.)

Call and consult with a BK attny that can go over your personal situation....way toooooo many variables to cover it all here.

Contributions to a voluntary retirement plan like your IRA can be listed in Schedule J, but the Trustee or U.S. Trustee may dispute them as being necessary if the amount of the retirement contribution is what brings your excess income below the level that is necessary to qualify for a Chapter 7. (The idea is that the retirement account is not necessary for your immediate survival; you could use that money to pay your creditors for a period of time instead.)

If you file a Chapter 7 with excess income of over a certain amount (from $100 to $!66.67, depending on your debt levels), you will likely be forced to dismiss your case or convert to a Chapter 13.

Because allowable expense amounts and types may vary from area to area, you should consult with an attorney who practices in the Central District (where you would file your case) to make sure that it runs smoothly. Excess income can cause a Chapter 7 filing to fail even if you pass the Means test.

You can usually deduct 401k contributions as a necessary expense. that will depend in part as to how much you have for retirement and how old you are...these issues are better determined by an experienced bankruptcy attorney who has knowledge of local practice.

The question is what expenses and what amounts are reasonable. Much has been written about this very topic. Making up expenses or increasing them solely for the purpose of filing bankruptcy is not allowed. Paying debts that will be discharged in bankruptcy is not a valid expenses. There are limits on expenses for school, expenses to support elderly relatives, and, in some places, mortgage payments. Starting up a retirement account on the eve of bankruptcy likewise has not been allowed in some courts. The rule of reason (in bankruptcy it is the totality of the circumstances) governs.

See a local bankruptcy attorney for a complete review of your income and expenses. The specifics of your situation will dictate the answer.
